:sparkles: **Welcome to GitHub Projects** :sparkles:
_This card is provided by GitHub as an introduction. You may delete it at any time_.

We're so excited that you've decided to create a new project! Now that you're here, let's make sure you know how to get the most out of GitHub Projects.
- [ ] Press the <kbd>?</kbd> key to see available keyboard shortcuts
- [ ] Drag and drop this card to the new column
- [ ] Search for and add issues or PRs to your project

**Cards**
Cards can be added to your board to track the progress of issues and pull requests. You can also add note cards, like this one!

**Automation**
[Automatically move your cards](https://help.github.com/articles/configuring-automation-for-project-boards/) to the right place based on the statu

Includes appropriate metadata in HTML (4pt)
- [ ] author
- [ ] description
- [ ] keywords 
- [ ] favicon

Appropriate page content (5pt)
- Page is a mock-up of the "main page" of a web app (not a landing page!)

Sufficient app content (5pt)
- [ ] at least 2-3 printed pages
- [ ] at least 3 images/media

Header and footer w/ appropriate information (3pt)
- [ ] includes name of app
- [ ] includes author/copyright

Mock interactivity (6pt)
- [ ] includes button or form link
- [ ] links to second page that is changed version page
- [ ] second page reuses stylesheet rules

Site is styled with CSS (8pt)
- [ ] includes custom CSS
- [ ] color specification
- [ ] font/text specification
- [ ] margin/padding specification

Content is navigable and readable (3pt)
- [ ] styling does not interfere with usage
- [ ] content is spatially organized

Includes "non-default" element flow via CSS (7pt)
- e.g., columns or grids
- [ ] effectively uses flexbox!

Accessibly semantic HTML usage (4pt)
- e.g., headings for headings, lists for lists

Uses sectioning elements (4pt)
- [ ] inclues e.g., `<header>` `<main>`, etc.
- [ ] used to appropriately structure the page
- [ ] headings are at appropriate levels

Alt text on images/visual elements (5pt)
- includes captions, `aria-labels`, other `aria` tags when necessary/appropriate
Specifies viewport meta for mobile devices (1pt)
Content is visible & available on small and large screens (1pt)

Follow mobile design principles (4pt)
- [ ] layout
- [ ] media
- [ ] fonts
- [ ] navigation
- [ ] inputs & interaction
- [ ] content
Alternate resolutions for large background images (1pt)

Layout is customized to different screen sizes (4pt)
- The page should "look different" for different devices with different affordances

Uses media queries (3pt)
- In a meaningful way!

Code takes a mobile-first approach (2pt)
- default styling is mobile, CSS media rules change that

Design is deeply considered and polished (6pt)

Including, but not limited to:
- [ ] coloring
- [ ] typography (fonts)
- [ ] positioning (spacing)

Includes appropriate engaging effects (8pt)

For example:
- box-shadow, border-radius, gradients, images
- detailed iconography (font-awesome)
- framework components (navbar, cards, wells, etc)
- (advanced) parallax
- (advanced) useful transforms, animations

Code is valid (2pt)
- [ ] includes doctype
- [ ] passes validators
- [ ] passes linters
No unnecessary/redundant HTML elements (2pt)

Appropriate CSS selectors (3pt)
- [ ] prefer class over id
- [ ] avoid duplicated CSS rules or properties
Informative CSS class & id names (2pt)

Overall code readability (3pt)
- [ ] cleanly indented
- [ ] well organized (especially CSS)

Includes organizing comments as necessary (1pt)
- [ ] HTML
- [ ] CSS
Published page to GitHub Pages (1pt)

Tagged commit with completed stage (2pt)
- [ ] tagged commit
- [ ] pushed tag
